ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Rather than letting a challenge overwhelm me, I imagined how to break the challenge down, developed a plan, and worked on it step-by-step.
At times when my mood was at its lowest, I stepped back and recognized that my self evaluations were probably overly negative.
I was aware of some specific patterns in negative thinking that have tended to affect the way I interpret new situations.
I made an effort to evaluate my negative thoughts by considering just the facts.
I examined evidence from my past or present to more carefully consider whether my negative thoughts are accurate or not.
When my negative thoughts and emotions really bothered me, I had a specific action plan of things I could do to cope.
When I had a negative emotional reaction, I noticed my negative thinking, and took time to evaluate my negative thoughts.
When I evaluated a situation as negative, I tried to think of how someone else would view the situation, and I used that to help me decide how to re-evaluate the situation myself.
I questioned my original negative thoughts and made an effort to develop alternative conclusions.
I recognized that negative feelings are related to negative thoughts I have about myself.
When I found myself upset about something, I took note of what I was thinking and worked to develop a more balanced view.
I recognized that beliefs I formed on the basis of past events and relationships may no longer be applicable in the same way today.
I have been recognizing that inaccurate, negative thoughts and judgments help to maintain my depression.
I have been aware of specific patterns in my negative thinking beliefs that tend to fuel my negative emotions.
When I found myself worrying that something bad would happen, I reminded myself that the consequences might not be so terrible even if it did happen.
When I made an effort to correct my negative thinking, I was confident that my mood would get better.
When I was upset, I made an effort to engage in enjoyable activities that would be likely to improve my mood.
When I have felt down, I engaged in activities that were enjoyable or gave me a sense of accomplishment (to try to help my mood).
I have been confident that if I made an effort to be less pessimistic, my mood would improve.
I caught myself thinking negatively, recognized the negative bias, and re-evaluated the situation.
I often caught myself thinking in an irrational way and I actively worked to develop more rational views.
When I had a task that I might have had trouble undertaking, I made an effort to break the task up into smaller parts.
I took time to review specific thoughts I had during the most upsetting parts of my day.
When I blamed myself for something bad that happened, I took time to consider other factors that may have been involved.
I believed that working to more carefully evaluate my negative thoughts would probably help ease my depression.
I noticed specific automatic thoughts as they occurred.
Rather than avoiding a difficult decision, I weighed my options, developed a solution, and followed through with the decision I made.
When I got upset, I took time to step back from a situation and consider that my negative thoughts might be inaccurate.

When I had a tough interpersonal issue to address, I thought through how to be assertive in addressing the issue, tried to anticipate obstacles I might encounter, and initiated a conversation on the topic.
Automatic Thoughts: Ability
Automatic Thoughts: Frequency
Automatic Thoughts: Independence
Behavioral Activation: Ability
Behavioral Activation: Frequency
Behavioral Activation: Independence
